literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Actor
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
Bruno Latour ... any thing that does modify a state of affairs by making a difference is an actor ... (Latour, 2005)p.71).
Terms Actor and Actant both refer to entities with the capacity to act. The "actant/actor" are used sometimes interchangeably, but the distinction can also be a key tool in ANT for analyzing the unfolding of agency (Matozzi, 2019)p.94). These entities participating in the action are not strictly (intentional) humans, but extends to include the "non-humans", i.e. anything that makes a difference (Latour, 2005)p.71-72).
Crucially for ANT, the term actor in "actor-network" is intentionally oxymoronic, embodying the tension between a centered "actor" and a decentered "network", thus eliding the distinction between "agency" and "structure" (Law, 1999)p.5). A defining aspect for both of them in ANT is that they make a difference. If an entity makes no difference, it is not considered an actor but a passive intermediary. An actor is thus what is not entirely substitutable. (Latour, 2005)p.130;153.)
"Actant" is often used when the entity does not yet have a specific figuration or identity beyond its capacity to act (Latour, 2005)p.71). Generally, it is used to point to "anything that acts" regardless of its ontological status, size, scale, or features, providing a descriptive term for the principle of symmetry (Matozzi, 2019)p.94). Actant is then a slightly broader term than actor, and often used in a more general and symmetrical way to include anything that participates in a network and influences outcomes, particularly before a stable identity or figuration is established.
"Actor" can then denote an actant with more specific features, relationships, and a recognized role within the network. Actor can be understood as an actant that possesses additional features and engages in various relations beyond simply performing an action. While anything that acts is an actant, what acts is not reducible solely to the performed action. For example (Akrich & Latour, 1992), a written note and a weight can both function as the same actant by reminding a hotel guest to return the key. However, in the given example they are different actors with distinct physical characteristics and may contribute differently to the hotel manager"s goals.
Figuration gives actants "flesh and features that make them have some form or shape, no matter how vague". These are not limited to anthropomorphic forms; they can also be e.g. ideo- or technomorphic. An actor is an actant that has been given a specific figuration. In ANT process, the analysis often involves moving from the identification of actants to the figuration of actors with more defined roles and attributes within a network. Therefore, the figuration that distinguishes the actor from the actant is one that endows the actant with specific characteristics, attributes agency to it, or positions it within a network in a defined way, moving beyond the basic definition of "anything that acts". (Latour, 2005)p.53-55.)
ANT treats actors symmetrically by employing a methodological principle known as generalized symmetry. This principle suggests that when studying a situation or a network, researchers should remain agnostic regarding what counts as an actor and should not a priori assume that humans and non-humans have fundamentally different types of agency or causal power. (Law, 2004)p.101-103;(Callon, 1986)p.201.)
ANT also proposes that agency is not an inherent property of individual actors (whether human or non-human) but rather an emergent effect of the relationships and associations within a network (Nimmo, 2011)p.112). Actors are seen as "network effects" because they do not possess inherent, fixed properties or agency in isolation. Instead, their characteristics, capabilities, and even their very existence are consequences of the relationships and connections they form and maintain within a heterogeneous network of other actors/actants - human and non-human. (Law & Hassard, 1999);(Law, 1999).
Bruno Latour ANT is not the empty claim that objects do things ‘instead’ of human actors ... It does not designate little goblins with red hats acting at atomic levels, only that the analyst should be prepared to look in order to account for the durability and extension of any interaction. (Latour, 2005)p.72.)

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Actor-Network Theory
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
John Law ... an approach to sociotechnical analysis that treats entities and materialities as enacted and relational effects, and explores the configuration and reconfiguration of those relations (Law, 2004)p.157).
Actor-Network Theory (ANT, fin. toimijaverkkoteoria) is often described as an approach, sensibility, program or orientation to relationality, materiality, heterogeneity and process for sociotechnical or -material analysis (Law, 2004)p.157);(Latour, 1999). It aims for empirical descriptions of the relational ties and sociomaterial flux and it's translations in a network (Latour, 2005). The unit of analysis is often process (Miettinen, 1999)p.174). Despite its name, whether it truly is a theory is debatable and there is even an a-theoretical nature to it (Latour, 2005).
ANT has its roots in the Centre de Sociologie de l'Innovation (CSI) of the Mines de Paris and emerged from the field of Science and Technology Studies (STS) in the early 1980s. It was/is often referred also to as "a sociology of translations" or "a sociology of associations" before the term Actor-Network Theory was coined. (Akrich, 2023);(Callon, 2001). Foundational scholars are considered to be Bruno Latour, Madeleine Akrich, John Law and Michel Callon. Other influential, but not at all peripheral, are e.g. Annemarie Mol, Steve Woolgar, Karin Knorr-Cetina and Donna Haraway. In the context of innovation systems, has Reijo Miettinen examined the applicability of ANT since the 1990s. As previously stated, it is well used, developed and debated in social sciences, but has been "spread" over various other fields and uses (Law, 1999)p.10)
ANT has evolved through the decades and because it lacks a theoretical unity it might be difficult to define (Miettinen, 1999)p.171). There is no generic way to apply ANT because there is no clear "methodological prescription", but there are many key elements and choices that persist in it's intellectual practice (Jackson, 2015) or show up in contemporary ANT "and After".
Key concepts, after (Jackson, 2015);(Walsham, 1997): Core concepts:
Actor
Actor-Network
Generalized Symmetry
(Ontological) Agnosticism
Heterogeneity Hybridity
Multiplicity Network dynamics:
Translation
Inscription (Device)
Intermediaries and Mediators
Punctualisation (Black Box) Immutable Mobile and Object
Obligatory Passage Point Quasi-Object Methodological considerations: Reflexivity
Method Assemblage From these key concepts we can conceive the following ordering:Note Actor-Network Theory views reality as constructed through dynamic networks of diverse actors, both human and non-human, treating them with generalized symmetry and ontological agnosticism. These actor-networks, characterized by heterogeneity and hybridity, are enacted through processes of translation, where e.g. inscriptions and quasi-objects facilitate interactions via intermediaries and mediators. Through enrolment, actants are integrated, and often networks have obligatory passage points where all actors must converge. Immutable mobiles and objects stabilize and disseminate influence, revealing the multiplicity inherent in social and material realities. Complex networks are often simplified into punctualised black boxes, which the ANT tries to provide a view into.
ANT does not use "society" or "social" as explanations in its analysis, but instead tries to explain them "in the making" as an ongoing achievement. It aims not to reproduce the classical oppositions or dualisms of nature/culture, micro/macro, agency/culture etc. or to see facts mirroring nature, but to show how they are constructed and to provide tools for analyzing that process. (Callon, 2001). It is thus a constructionist, post-structuralist, material-semiotic and an anti-essentialist approach. In the context of innovation processes, ANT is commonly used to study them as a simultaneous development of an artefact and a network of actors connected to it (Miettinen, 1999)p.170).ANT and After; Near ANT; methodology
Methodological principles (Latour, 2005);(Law, 2004);(Bignetti et al., 2023) Follow the actors Radical empiricism No pre-defined social Focus on associations Translation, not diffusion Description, not explanation first Symmetry principle Non-Euclideanity
In many ways a similar approach called the Social Construction of Technology (SCOT, foundational authors being Wiebe Bijker & Trevor Pinch) can not be accounted as ANT, according to (Latour, 2005)p. 10-11), since in it the "the social is kept stable all along and accounts for the shape of technological change." Another similarly kept approach is the Cultural Historical Activity Theory (AT or CHAT), which has a different disciplinary and philosophical background, but shares many methodological grounds (Miettinen, 1999). A closely related and broader body of thought is New Materialism, which it shares with e.g. the "flat" ontology and in some sense ANT (and perhaps also AT) can be seen as a contribution to it (Kamp, 2019).
Although ANT is historically based in the sociology of science and technology, according to (Miettinen, 1999)p.181) the ANT task for innovation processes "seems hopeless". ......

literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.title: Translation
literature-survey/framework/ant-and-afte.description:
Michel Callon Translation is the mechanism by which the social and natural worlds progressively take form (Callon, 1986)p.224).
Michel Callon This methodological choice through which society is rendered as uncertain and disputable as nature, reveals an unusual reality which is accounted for quite faithfully by the vocabulary of translation (Callon, 1986)p.222).
Rather than viewing the social as a separate domain, ANT sees it as an effect of heterogeneous associations (Latour, 2005). Within ANT, the concept of translation is central to understanding how these associations are formed and maintained. Developed by Michel Serres and then articulated by Michel Callon, translation emphasizes the continuity of displacements and transformations that occur within a story, project - a process (Callon, 1986).
Four Moments of Translation, after (Callon, 1986) 1. Problematization
Initial attempt by an actor to define a problem and to position other actors in relation to it. 2. Interessement Attempts to persuade other actors to accept the definitions and roles proposed in the problematization. 3. Enrolment
Actors negotiate and define their roles within the network, establishing stable relationships and a working network. 4. Mobilization The enrolled actors are expected to act collectively and in accordance with the roles defined for them as a single agent.
Initially the semiotic relations were "left open", but contemporarily ANT highlights how links are made between different entities, focusing on the work of making two things that are not the same, equivalent (Law, 1999)p.8). So it is not just a linguistic phenomenon but also a semiotic operation involving the displacement of logical relations between seemingly opposed sets of significations, interests, and concerns (Callon, 1980)p.211);(Brown & Capdevila, 1999)p.32).
The diffusion model is a way of understanding how facts, artefacts etc. spread in time and space, that ANT critiques as being overly simplistic. The diffusion model suggests that once a fact or artifact is established, people easily agree to transmit it, as if the object itself forces their assent. This model often invents a form of technological determinism, where innovations seem to spread with their own inherent strength, irresistibly imposing themselves, as if having their own vis inertia and explaingin non-adoption as mere "resistance". Contrarily, the translation model emphasizes that an innovation's journey involves active work in shaping and building a network of heterogenous relationships. The interests of different actors (again: human and non-human) are negotiated and potentially transformed in relation to the innovation, an the innovation itself may very well be transformed as it moves through different contexts and encounters different actors. (Latour, 1987)p.132-144.)The translation model tries to provide a richer understanding of how innovations travel and transform the socio-material worlds by focusing on the dynamic processes of network construction, the active roles of diverse actors, and the ongoing negotiations and transformations that shape their trajectories. It moves beyond a simple linear model of spread to examine the complex web of relationships and actions that constitute innovation in practice.

literature-survey/framework/philosophy/o.title: Ontology
literature-survey/framework/philosophy/o.description: ANT emphasizes a relational ontology, where reality is not assumed as given but arises from the practices, relationships, and effects of various actors (human and nonhuman) that associate and dissociate in different arrangements.

literature-survey/framework/si/innovatio.title: Innovation System
literature-survey/framework/si/innovatio.description: The term has been introduced from research into politics. In politics and policy it has been recognized to work as a loose border object rather than well defined and explanatory scientific term, in a similar way that Porters ideas have been used in policymaking. Innovation systems cannot be quantitatively compared in a fruitful way: they have to be situated and can't be generalized very well. This makes case studies an important way to gain understanding of innovation systems. (Miettinen, 2002).

literature-survey/methodology/digital-ga.title: Digital Garden
literature-survey/methodology/digital-ga.description:
#partiallyAIgenerated Examples
Discrete Structures for Computer Science On discrete mathematics for computer science majors, by R. Talbert.
Nokia Design Archive Interactive portal for Aalto University's project (Valtonen, Julier, Savola et. al.)
A Pattern Language Digitized C. Alexander's 1977 book on architecture, urban design and communities.
Scaling Synthesis A "living hypertext notebook" for a research project. A digital garden is a metaphor for an online space where thoughts, ideas, and notes are cultivated and interconnected over time. In online space it's distinct e.g. from a traditional blog in several key ways. Unlike many types of texts, which are typically published and then left as static pieces, digital garden entries are meant to be living documents that are constantly updated, revised, and expanded upon. The focus is on the process of developing ideas, rather than presenting finished products.
Digital gardens often utilize extensive internal linking to create a network of interconnected ideas. This somewhat resembles the idea of pattern language and allows readers to explore related concepts and follow the evolution of the author's thinking. This linking creates a non linear way of navigating the information. Digital gardens are often highly personal spaces where individuals can explore their own interests and develop their own unique perspectives. It is a place for the author to cultivate their own thoughts.In essence, a digital garden is a space for continuous learning, reflection, and connection, where ideas are nurtured and allowed to grow organically.

literature-survey/methodology/pattern-la.title: Pattern Language
literature-survey/methodology/pattern-la.description:
#partiallyAIgenerated
The concept of pattern language was popularized by architect Christopher Alexander and his colleagues in their book, "A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction" @alexanderPatternLanguageTowns1977. While originating in architecture, the concept of pattern languages has been applied to other fields, including software engineering, where "design patterns" are used to document and share best practices. The concept isn't applied or practiced in this project, but its philosophy is adjacent to the Digital Garden you're currently reading at. See also the Wikipedia articleEssentially, a pattern language is: A System of Solutions: It's an organized set of "patterns," where each pattern describes a recurring problem and offers a core solution that can be adapted to various contexts. Design Guidance: It provides a framework for designing and building environments, from entire towns to individual rooms, in a way that promotes human well-being and a sense of place. Interconnected Patterns: The patterns are interconnected, forming a "language" that allows designers and builders to create cohesive and harmonious environments. Focus on Human Experience: The patterns are rooted in observations of how people interact with their surroundings and aim to create spaces that support positive human experiences. Key aspects of a pattern language include: Patterns as Problem-Solution Pairs: Each pattern consists of a description of a common problem, followed by a proposed solution. Contextual Solutions: The solutions are not rigid formulas but rather guidelines that can be adapted to specific contexts and needs. Hierarchical Structure: The patterns are organized in a hierarchical structure, ranging from large-scale patterns (e.g., urban planning) to small-scale patterns (e.g., room details).

literature-survey/scholars/annemarie-mol.title: Annemarie Mol
literature-survey/scholars/annemarie-mol.description:
#AIgeneratedInfo Known for her work on the body, illness, and medical practices, emphasizing the multiplicity of reality and how practices shape it.
Reference Google Scholar
Uni. of Amsterdam profile

literature-survey/scholars/bruno-latour..title: Bruno Latour
literature-survey/scholars/bruno-latour..description:
#AIgenerated Info A key figure in Actor-Network Theory (ANT), he explored how science and technology are shaped by networks of human and non-human actors.
Reference Personal website

literature-survey/scholars/donna-haraway.title: Donna Haraway
literature-survey/scholars/donna-haraway.description:
#AIgenerated Info Famous for her work on feminism, technology, and science, particularly her concept of the "cyborg" and her critiques of traditional dualisms.
Reference UC Santa Cruz profile

literature-survey/scholars/john-law.html.title: John Law
literature-survey/scholars/john-law.html.description:
#AIgenerated Info A major contributor to ANT, focusing on how social realities are enacted through practices and networks.
Reference Personal website

literature-survey/scholars/madeleine-akr.title: Madeleine Akrich
literature-survey/scholars/madeleine-akr.description:
#AIgenerated Info One of the "founders" of ANT, known for her work on the dynamic relationships between users and technologies, particularly on how user representations are embedded within technological designs and how users adapt and transform those technologies.
Reference CSI profile
Google Scholar

literature-survey/scholars/michel-callon.title: Michel Callon
literature-survey/scholars/michel-callon.description:
#AIgenerated Info Another central figure in ANT, his work examines how economic and scientific activities are shaped by networks and performative practices.
Reference Google Scholar
CSI profile

literature-survey/scholars/michel-serres.title: Michel Serres
literature-survey/scholars/michel-serres.description:
#AIgenerated Info Michel Serres, with his emphasis on fluid networks, translations, and the interconnectedness of humans and non-humans, provided crucial philosophical groundwork for Actor-Network Theory's focus on heterogeneous associations.
Reference L'Académie française

literature-survey/scholars/reijo-miettin.title: Reijo Miettinen
literature-survey/scholars/reijo-miettin.description:
#AIgenerated Info He is known for his work connecting STS with activity theory, and analyzing the development of scientific and technological practices in relation to human activity.
Reference Google Scholar
Uni. of Helsinki profile

literature-survey/scholars/wiebe-bijker..title: Wiebe Bijker
literature-survey/scholars/wiebe-bijker..description:
#AIgenerated Info A key figure in the social construction of technology (SCOT), he studies how the design and development of technology are influenced by social factors.
Reference Google Scholar

research-plan/research-plan.html.title: Research Plan
research-plan/research-plan.html.description:
Last updated 7.3.2025 Info Janne W. Matilainen (janne.matilainen@lapinamk.fi) University of Lapland - Faculty of Social Sciences Lapland University of Applied Sciences - Smart Built Environment Research field: Social Sciences - Management/Organization Studies Keywords (YSO): actor-network theory, innovation system, innovation policy, regions, research and development operations, university of applied science The Universities of Applied Sciences (UAS) in Finland have an applied and regional role in the Finnish innovation systems. Their research, development and innovation (RDI) activities are changing, gaining maturity and beginning to find their characteristic ways of operation. One of these ways are the service concepts branded around some core demand or competence, which conduct RDI in co-operation with small and medium enterprises (SME) utilizing applied and practical methods. Their purpose is to aid commercial actors with their industry-recognized problems to grow regional competitiveness. This research aims to understand how these applied RDI service concepts work socio-technically, and to examine their role in their respective UAS and more broadly in different systems of innovation. The research adopts a social constructivist views of technical innovation to explain the inner workings of these RDI organizations in relation to relevant innovation systems. Main theoretical backgrounds and lenses are those of actor-network theory (ANT) and systems of innovation (SI). The research is a case study with an ethnographic nature, based on ANT, avoiding purely social or technological explanations. The study utilizes traditional qualitative methods associated with ethnographies. The case to be studied are the service concepts of TEQU and Frostbit in Lapland UAS. The deliverable result is a rich description about networks, interactions and translations in and with these technologically oriented RDI organizations and the identified innovation systems. These objectives can be valued as societal, as the UAS’s RDI role in the national innovation system is in motion. Innovation systems can be seen as complex networks of actors and institutions that interact to create, facilitate and disseminate knowledge. The impacts pursued with this study are to evoke discussion in both theoretical and societal dimensions. Theoretical discussions this research contributes are innovation management and diffusion of innovations. Societal discussion it partakes in is innovation policy and the role of UAS’s in innovation systems in Finland. Premise underpinning the research: The project is a continuum of previous research done about Finnish UASs, RDI and innovation systems. Research’s premise is that the Finnish UASs ways of practicing RDI with SME-oriented service concepts enacts innovation systems. It's also assumed that instead of purely technological or academic work they construct solution-oriented socio-technical ensembles that differ from the more traditionally held linear innovation models. Research questions: in the context of public-private RDI-activities performed by the Lapland UAS' RDI concepts in regional settings. What are the actor-networks of the RDI service concepts? What do they consist of and how are they formed and maintained? How they define goals and what leads to their perceived success or failure? What are the key characteristics that enable or constrain their innovation processes? How do they relate to some perceived "innovation systems"? Do the RDI-activities enact innovation systems? What is their role in regional competitiveness? What kinds of models of innovation do they hold?
See attached Toulmin Argument. Expected research results: The aim and objective of this project is to create an ANT and SI inspired rich socio-technical ethnographic description about these kinds of service concepts (case studies: TEQU & Frostbit of Lapland UAS) in relation to and their roles in systems of innovation. Work plan and schedule: The project is to be done as a part-time research, working full-time with the Lapland UAS.
See attached link to the Gantt-chart. Research data and methods: Observation notes, interviews, surveys and public & internal documents. The rich description is constructed with qualitative ethnographic methods, utilizing an actor-network theory -type of framework. The data to form this description is collected with participative and non-participative observations, interviews and surveys. Document analysis is also used to aid and supplement the qualitative interpretation. No codified preliminary data, but a six-year working experience about the RDI service concepts in question, which hastens the formal observatory methods’ implementation. Short comparative or enriching inquiries about The Research Institute of Measuring and Modelling for the Built Environment (MeMo) and Jamk University of Applied Sciences are also possible. Informed consent is gathered from the participants, and their right and ways to modify or withdraw that consent is informed and ensured. Data considering any participants/subjects is anonymized and handled according to good practices on the type of data in question. Monograph: A body of texts will be produced in hypertext/markdown format in Obisidian environment. Interlinked body of hypertext builds a type of a "Wiki" or "pattern language" about the research. The monograph will be compiled mainly from these texts. Risk assessment: Main risk for implementation is the possible delay of the project due to part-time research. The research is thus designed to have as little timing-sensitive parts as possible, to enable flexible and resilient implementation. No ethical issues or ethical reviews foreseen. Self- and faculty monitoring practiced. Scientific: The scientific impact pursued with this research is to “open the black box” of RDI in Finnish UASs in regional systems of innovation. It aims to renew the discussion about technically oriented RDI work in these types of institutions and their stakeholders, with not purely technological or social reasons, but taking to account them both. According to bibliometric searches there is little research about these types of organizations in frameworks of ANT and management, but the project is not novel as an ANT or STS study and no special potential for scientific breakthroughs is expected. Open science: Open-access wide-audience publication (publ. type E/D) at the start/mid phase of the project to market the project and promote societal discussion. Lapland University Consortium open-access channels are preferred, in Finnish. One publication in wider-audience professional or scientific publication (publ. type D/B). Open-access publications considering Universities of Applied Sciences are preferred, joint publication with stakeholders or academic partners favored, in Finnish or English. Open-access publishing of Obsidian library/vault as a "digital garden", to communicate the research "in the making". Beyond academia: Discussion with Universities of Applied Sciences, Regional Councils and other RDI funders, SME's and RDI policy makers are promoted.

headers.heading: Unboxing the RDI from Innovation Systems

research-plan/table-of-contents-for-mono.title: Table of Contents for Monograph
research-plan/table-of-contents-for-mono.description: Caution DRAFT 16.2.2025 #partiallyAIgenerated Background, Context and Intentions: Sets the stage for the research topic, its significance and potential impact. Scope of this Research: Defines the scope and focus to provide direction, discussions it participates and justifications for the research. Research Questions: Clearly states the central research questions guiding the study. Conceptual Framework: Outlines the chosen theoretical lenses/frameworks and their relations and justifies their use. Background Theory: Actor-Network Theory doesn't adhere very well onto traditional background/focal/data theory sets. Focal Theory: Data Theory: On Form and Content: Elaborates and comments on the structure, contents and style of the dissertation. Overview of Relevant Literature: Reviews existing literature related to the research topic and chosen approach. Introduction to Systems of Innovation: Briefly outlines SI framework, including core tenets like systems thinking and interdependencies. Introduction to Actor-Network Theory: Briefly outlines the core tenets of ANT, including key concepts and their application to study Systems of Innovation. Applications in Previous Research: Reviews existing research related to the research topic using similar approaches. Critical Engagement: Discusses key debates and critiques within ANT scholarship, supplemented with SI and NM and their alternative perspectives. Research Design: Describes the chosen research approach (e.g., ethnography, case study etc.). Case Study: Introduces the specific case or phenomenon under investigation. Data Collection: Details the methods used to gather data (e.g., interviews, non-/participative observations, document analysis). Data Analysis: Explains how data will be analyzed through an ANT lens (e.g., identifying actants, mapping networks, analyzing translation processes) and how it identifies the innovation system. Ethical Considerations: Presentation of Empirical Findings: Tracing the Network Dynamics: Analyzes how the actants interact, form alliances, and influence each other within the network. Translation and Inscription Processes: Identifies and analyzes how meanings, interests, and resources are translated between actants. Key Events and Transformations: Findings and Interpretations: Summarizes the key findings of the study and discusses their implications in the light of chosen approach. Theoretical and Practical Implications: To the Field of Study: Explains how the study contributes to the development and application of ANT and SI and discusses the broader implications of the findings for the relevant field of study. To the UAS' and Policy Makers: Limitations of the Study: and FRIN Summary of Key Findings: Briefly restates the main findings and contributions of the study compared to the research questions. Concluding Remarks: Offers final thoughts and reflections on the research, limitations, and potential avenues for future research.
research-plan/table-of-contents-for-mono.sourcePath: Research Plan/Table of Contents for Monograph.md

research-plan/toulmin-argument.html.title: Toulmin Argument
research-plan/toulmin-argument.html.description:
Last updated
3.3.2025
Grounds
Empirical observations reveal a network of heterogenous actors working in a setting that aims for the development of regional competitiveness by the means of innovation.
And sinceWarrant
The flux of these actions constitutes as the practical enactment and materialization of social reality.
On account ofBacking
Actor-network theory (and after) and innovation system studies.
And becauseQualifier
These grounds can be seen as a description of the social reality of innovation systems.
SoClaim
Finnish UAS's RDI concepts actively contribute to the construction and realization of different innovation systems.
UnlessRebuttal
We deny this type of description having explanatory power over the social reality.

zotero_literaturenotes/@bignettiactornet.title: @bignettiActornetworkTheoryMethodological2023
zotero_literaturenotes/@bignettiactornet.description: Cite Bignetti, B., De Souza, A. C. A. A., & Petrini, M. (2023). Actor-network theory: Methodological issues in practice. Qualitative Research in Organizations and Management: An International Journal, 18(2), 142–162. https://doi.org/10.1108/QROM-05-2022-2337 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Bignetti, Bernardo Author:: De Souza, Ana Clara Aparecida Alves Author:: Petrini, Maira ~ Title:: Actor-network theory: methodological issues in practice Year:: 2023 Citekey:: bignettiActornetworkTheoryMethodological2023 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Qualitative Research in Organizations and Management: An International Journal Volume:: 18 Issue:: 2 Pages:: 142-162 DOI:: 10.1108/QROM-05-2022-2337 Link . Abstract Purpose This study demonstrates a practical use of Actor-Network Theory (ANT), showing methodological, predictive and unforeseen issues that emerged during the data collection and analysis phases and how they were addressed during the development of this research. Design/methodology/approach Based on the research of reapplication of a “tecnologia social” (TS) of entrepreneurial education, this article explores the author’s reflections on the adoption of ANT as a theoretical-methodological approach, highlighting the practical implications of a social material theory during fieldwork. Findings The adoption of ANT places the researcher in front of methodological issues not always foreseen in the research design. Four moments to a practical path through the engagement of ANT agency are highlighted: the network of actors, monitoring of actors, interpretation of data collected and writing results. These moments correspond to methodological issues that the authors faced during the practical journey of the research. At each moment, the challenge aroused is discussed and the methodological choice chosen to address the issue is presented. Originality/value The engagement with ANT has enormous potential in the study of management and organizations phenomenon, but its methodological implications in practice are still challenging. The authors seek to share this investigation and engagement in ANT so that other researchers have a reference and a starting point to employ and engage in this theoretical-methodological lens. Thus, it may be possible to anticipate certain difficulties in future research designs and to glimpse at potential developments and paths that the research may lead. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@brownperpetuummo.title: @brownPerpetuumMobileSubstance1999
zotero_literaturenotes/@brownperpetuummo.description: Cite Brown, S. D., & Capdevila, R. (1999). Perpetuum Mobile: Substance, Force and the Sociology of Translation. The Sociological Review, 47(1), 26–50. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03481.x Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Brown, Steven D. Author:: Capdevila, Rose ~> FirstEditor:: Law, John Editor:: Hassard, John ~ Title:: Perpetuum Mobile : Substance, Force and the Sociology of Translation Year:: 1999 Citekey:: brownPerpetuumMobileSubstance1999 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: The Sociological Review Volume:: 47 Issue:: 1 Pages:: 26-50 DOI:: 10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03481.x Link . Abstract Going after means taking up a position with regard to something and the active pursuit of that same thing. It is the critical move par excellence, but also an act of appropriation. This essay suspends the urge to go after in preference for an exploration of the trajectory of that body of texts known as the sociology of translation. The figure of the perpetuum mobile is put into circulation through these texts in order to trace some of their more unusual and unfamiliar connections. These include a whole series of parallels with seventeenth century classical philosophy and with nineteenth century ‘social energetics’. Connections are drawn out by using three ‘test signals’, which are sent on through the ANT canon: substance, force and time. Pivotal to each is the sense of how very different events and apparently diverse territories can be brought into contiguity, or folded up together. This contiguity needs to be performed rather than described, placed in translation rather than simply presented. The chapter concludes by tracing a way from the strange folds of ANT to the equally peculiar forms of early Psychology. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@delaetzimbabwebu.title: @delaetZimbabweBushPump2000
zotero_literaturenotes/@delaetzimbabwebu.description: Cite De Laet, M., & Mol, A. (2000). The Zimbabwe Bush Pump: Mechanics of a Fluid Technology. Social Studies of Science, 30(2), 225–263. https://doi.org/10.1177/030631200030002002 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: De Laet, Marianne Author:: Mol, Annemarie ~ Title:: The Zimbabwe Bush Pump: Mechanics of a Fluid Technology Year:: 2000 Citekey:: delaetZimbabweBushPump2000 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Social Studies of Science Volume:: 30 Issue:: 2 Pages:: 225-263 DOI:: 10.1177/030631200030002002 Link . Abstract In this paper we investigate the intricacies of an admirable water pumping device - the Zimbabwe Bush Pump B' type - so as to find out what makes it an appropriate technology'. This turns out to be what we call the fluidity' of the pump (of its boundaries, or of its working order, and of its maker). We find that in travelling to intractable places, an object that isn't too rigorously bounded, that doesn't impose itself but tries to serve, that is adaptable, flexible and responsive - in short, a fluid object - may well prove to be stronger than one which is firm. By analyzing the success and failure of this device, its agency and the way in which it shapes new configurations in the Zimbabwean socio-technical landscape, we partake in the current move in science and technology studies to transform what it means to be an actor. And by mobilizing the term love for articulating our relation to the Bush Pump, we try to contribute to shaping novel ways of doing' normativity. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@kampactornetwork.title: @kampActorNetworkTheory2019
zotero_literaturenotes/@kampactornetwork.description: Cite Kamp, A. (2019). Actor–Network Theory. Teoksessa A. Kamp, Oxford Research Encyclopedia of Education. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/acrefore/9780190264093.013.526 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstBookauthor:: Kamp, Annelies ~> FirstAuthor:: Kamp, Annelies ~ Title:: Actor–Network Theory Year:: 2019 Citekey:: kampActorNetworkTheory2019 itemType:: bookSection Book:: Publisher:: Oxford University Press ISBN:: 978-0-19-026409-3 Link . Abstract Actor–network theory (ANT) is an approach to research that sits with a broader body of new materialism; a body of work that displaces humanism to consider dynamic assemblages of humans and nonhumans. Originally developed in the social studies of science and technology undertaken in the second half of the 20th century, ANT has increasingly been taken up in other arenas of social inquiry. Researchers working with ANT do not accept the unquestioned use of “social” explanations for educational phenomena. Rather, the social, like all other effects, is taken to be an enactment of heterogenous assemblages of human and nonhuman entities. The role of the educational researcher is to trace these processes of assemblage and reassemblage, foregrounding the ways in which certain entities establish sufficient allies to assume some degree of “realness” in the world. Aligning most closely with ethnographic orientations, ANT does not outline a method. However, it could be argued that a number of propositions are shared in ANT-inspired approaches: first, that the world is made up of actors/actants, all of which are ontologically symmetrical. Humans are not privileged in ANT. Second, the principle of irreduction—there is no essence within or beyond any process of assemblage. Actors are concrete; there is no “potential” other than their actions in the moment. Entities are nothing more than an effect of assemblage. Third, the concept of translation and its processes of mediation that transform objects when they encounter one another. Finally, the principle of alliance. Actants gain strength only through their alliances. These propositions have specific implications for data generation, analysis, and reporting. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@latourrecallinga.title: @latourRecallingAnt1999
zotero_literaturenotes/@latourrecallinga.description: Cite Latour, B. (1999). On Recalling Ant. The Sociological Review, 47(1), 15–25. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03480.x Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Latour, Bruno ~ Title:: On Recalling Ant Year:: 1999 Citekey:: latourRecallingAnt1999 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: The Sociological Review Volume:: 47 Issue:: 1 Pages:: 15-25 DOI:: 10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03480.x Link . Abstract The paper explores one after the other the four difficulties of actor-network theory, that is the words ‘actor’, ‘network’ and ‘theory’—without forgetting the hyphen. It tries to refocus the originality of what is more a method to deploy the actor's own world building activities than an alternative social theory. Finally, it sketches some of its remaining potential. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@lawantcomplexity.title: @lawAntComplexityNaming1999
zotero_literaturenotes/@lawantcomplexity.description: Cite Law, J. (1999). After Ant: Complexity, Naming and Topology. The Sociological Review, 47(1), 1–14. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03479.x Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Law, John ~> FirstEditor:: Hassard, John Editor:: Law, John ~ Title:: After Ant: Complexity, Naming and Topology Year:: 1999 Citekey:: lawAntComplexityNaming1999 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: The Sociological Review Volume:: 47 Issue:: 1 Pages:: 1-14 DOI:: 10.1111/j.1467-954X.1999.tb03479.x Link . Abstract What is a theory? Or, more broadly, what is a good way of addressing intellectual problems? This paper explores the tension central to the notion of an ‘actor’ - ‘network’ which is an intentionally oxymoronic term that combines—and elides the distinction between—structure and agency. It then notes that this tension has been lost as ‘actor-network’ has been converted into a smooth and consistent ‘theory’ that has been (too) simply and easily displaced, criticised or applied. It recalls another term important to the actor-network approach—that of translation— which is another term in tension, since (the play of words works best in the romance languages) to translate is to also betray ( traductore, tradition). It is suggested that in social theory simplicity should not displace the complexities of tension. The chapter concludes by exploring a series of metaphors for grappling with tensions rather than wishing these away, and in particular considers the importance of topological complexity, and the notion of fractionality. Today we have naming of parts. Yesterday, We had daily cleaning. And tomorrow morning, We shall have what to do after firing. But today, Today we have naming of parts. Japonica Glistens like coral in all of the neighbouring gardens, And today we have naming of parts.' (Henry Reed, Lessons of the War: 1) . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@nimmoactornetwor.title: @nimmoActorNetworkTheoryMethodology2011
zotero_literaturenotes/@nimmoactornetwor.description:
Cite Nimmo, R. (2011). Actor-Network Theory and Methodology: Social Research in a More-Than-Human World. Methodological Innovations Online, 6(3), 108–119. https://doi.org/10.4256/mio.2011.010 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Nimmo, Richie ~ Title:: Actor-Network Theory and Methodology: Social Research in a More-Than-Human World Year:: 2011 Citekey:: nimmoActorNetworkTheoryMethodology2011 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Methodological Innovations Online Volume:: 6 Issue:: 3 Pages:: 108-119 DOI:: 10.4256/mio.2011.010
Link Kokoteksti. Abstract This article explores the methodological implications of actor-network theory for social research. Pointing to an increasing awareness of ANT in sociological discourse, but assuming that it is more widely known than well understood, the article outlines some of the key features of ANT as an approach to social life, before addressing the tricky question of how these ideas translate into methodological practice. The possibilities of the approach are illustrated by reference to the author's own ANT-inspired historical research on the socio-material history of dairy milk in the UK, which is used as a point of reference and an example throughout. Particular attention is given to the practical method deployed in the milk study, namely documentary historiography, leading to a critical exploration of the use of ANT in the analysis of historical texts. This involves considering the nature of the relationship between texts and lived practices, and drawing out how ANT offers a distinctive way of seeing texts which challenges the standard ethnographic view of texts and fundamentally transforms the issue. Given that documentary historiography is not a method strongly associated with actor-network theory because it raises considerable methodological dilemmas, this provides one particular account of how such dilemmas can be managed or overcome. Social researchers interested in the potential of actor-network theory should be able to draw upon this in exploring the possibilities of the approach for their own work. . .

index.html.title: Index
index.html.description:
This website is for publishing my research project while it happens. During the research i build a body of texts in a format of hypertext, with a simple markup language (fin. merkintäkieli) called Markdown. What that means, is that these texts link into each other constituting a non-linear repository where the contents relate to each other. For a taste of this you can jump straight into the Actor-Network Theory note, my Research Plan or see examples of similar (or way fancier) implementations in the Digital Garden note.
All of this is managed in a personal knowledge base system called Obsidian. This repository in Obsidian is called a Vault. When it's published, it can be described with terms such as Digital Garden or Wiki (without the possibility for reader editing). This site has been translated straight from my Obsidian Vault into a www-publishable HTML with Nathan George's HTML Export Plugin. It is then hosted in and published with GitHub and it's Pages functionality.Info This is very much a work in progress. The maturity of the content lives and that's kinda the whole point of it. Not a single note is permanent, fixed or "ready". Also not everything in my Vault will be published right away. This site itself is a static epoch of my Vault and has to be manually updated into the web whenever wanted to. The project has started: 1.1.2025 This site has launched: 7.3.2025 Last web update: 3.4.2025 Currently working on: Literature survey, for Framework design Methods design Caution The functionalities of this website are not perfect. Translating from Obsidian flavoured Markdown to HTML (with all the third-party plugins that i use) does not mirror my Vault perfectly. I focus on content, but will gladly hear of any hiccups in the user interface. Main problems are: Citations using Pandoc citation keys have their technical restrictions and might not be presented in the most conventional or human-readable format. Site's layout has it's quirks, for example mobile device accessibility is not good and listings may have unnecessary line breaks.
Schedules written in Markwhen do not work in web view. Contact The purpose of this site is to promote open science, -source and -access, so i welcome any comments, questions, suggestions etc. from all grounds. Janne W. Matilainen Lapland University Consortium Rovaniemi, Lapland, Finland 66°28'51"N 25°43'18"E
janne.matilainen@lapinamk.fi
This work © 2025 is licensed under CC BY-SA 4.0

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
